title: About Me
content: A short description about me. post Personal About Me Chandra Mouli Gunturi is a top-graduating MSc Electronics (2024) student from Queen's University Belfast, where he developed a novel quad-copter altitude control algorithm for his final project. He received a first class undergrad degree in Electrical and Electronics Engineering (E.E.E) from P.V.P Siddhartha Institute of Technology in 2021.He interned at Cummins Inc as an Electronic Systems Engineer from 2023 to 2024, where he contributed to the development of a Wireless Sensor Control Unit (W-SCU), Active Cell Balancing Circuit amongst other projects. Whilst interning at Cummins, he also worked on Electronic Parking Brake (EPB) systems and authored a Cummins Technical Report on optimal design of temperature measurement circuits.He is currently working at Randox Laboratories Ltd, as an Electrical and Electronics Design Engineer. Where his responsibilities include designing Electrical and Electronic systems up to various internationally recognised standards, designing analogue and digital circuits, and developing industrial automation solutions using Siemens PLCs.His career interests span the fields of Applied Mathematics, Control Engineering, Autonomous Robotics, Swarms, Electrical, Electronics and Computer Science engineering.

title: Arduino
content: Embedded programming of AVR micro-controllers using the Arduino platform. Electronics Embedded Systems Arduino Aim:The articles in this sub-base aim to showcase and explain the implementation details of embedded systems through the programming of Arduino UNO. The code will be mainly written in C++ and we will be using Arduino IDE 2.0.Though, we will be programming an Arduino UNO using the Arduino IDE, each article will cover both bare-metal programming and its equivalent Arduino high-level functions. For demonstration purposes, with the intention to maintain a cleaner look, the results will be showcased using the online platform Tinkercad by Autodesk. It is a really good website to build and test simple circuits, and will help you get started on embedded programming without having to get an actual Arduino. Although, if you can, I would highly recommend getting an Arduino/ Arduino Kit from the official shop at Arduino.cc or any arduino engineering kits available from stores of your preference. Following along with actual hardware would benefit you a lot and the experience adds up overtime.TopicsArduino IDE BasicsHow to install Arduino IDE, create a new sketch, and configure.Arduino Ports BasicsIO maps and register configurations.Digital IOHow to use digital pins on Arduino as an Input or an Output.

title: Digital IO
content: This article covers how to control digital IO on Arduino UNO R3. Electronics Embedded Systems Arduino PrerequisitesThough this article deals with a very fundamental topic in embedded systems, it is assumed that the reader already has the knowledge of the following topics.LED biasing and the use of current limiting resistors.The use of pull-ups or pull-downs.Creating a new sketch on the Arduino IDE and configuring com-port.Basic of C and bit manipulation using bit-wise operators in C.Optional: IO registers and port manipulation theory.The Aim:This article aims to explain how to manipulate the digital IO ports on Arduino UNO. For this, we will utilise the digital pins 12 and 13 on the UNO board. Going forward these digital pins will be referred to as pin 12 and pin 13 respectively.The Plan:Pin 13 on the Arduino UNO board is connected to the anode of an on-board LED. We can use this LED as a visual indicator when pin 13 is being manipulated.First, we plan to learn to use pin 13 in output mode, and then pin 12 in input mode. In output mode, we want to turn ON/OFF the on-board LED using a simple C++ program (the program is also called as a sketch in the Arduino environment). We then explore how to utilise the pin 12 in input mode and read the state of input on the pin. The reason for selecting pin 12 for input and pin 13 for output is because we can write logic to visually indicate changes on pin 12 by controlling the LED on pin 13 accordingly.The reader should be aware that the mode of operation and data manipulation of the IO pins on any micro-controller in general are controlled by configuring (setting or clearing bits) architecture specific registers. Don't worry, the article should still serve you, if you do not know how this works.Arduino UNO IO MappingThough the pin we want to manipulate is referred to as pin 13 in the Arduino environment, on the PCB this pin is wired to pin 5 of Port-B on the AVR ATMEGA328P micro-controller. We will refer to this as PB5 in short. So, pin 13 is the alias given to pin 5 of Port-B in the Arduino environment.The reader is encouraged to visit the official Arduino UNO R3 documentation page and check out the Advanced Section of the Pinout pdf.Output ModeThe IO mode of pin 5 of Port-B on ATMEGA328P can be configured by setting bit-5 of the corresponding Data Direction Register for Port-B (DDRB). This can be done as,// You can use any of the following 5 notations and they are equivalent// Using 8-bit Binary notationDDRB = ( DDRB | 0b00100000);// Using 8-bit Hex notationDDRB = (DDRB | 0x20);// Short-hand notation using compound assignment operatorDDRB |= (0x20); // this is equivalent to writing DDRB = (DDRB | 0x20)// Using bit-wise left shift operatorDDRB |= (1 &lt&lt 5);// Using DDB5 existing macroDDRB |= (1 &lt&lt DDB5); // PreferredGoing forward, we will prefer the last notations as it is both compact and readable. The macro DDB5 can be read as Data Direction register port-B bit 5 and it resolves to a literal constant of vale 5.Now, we can set (HIGH) bit 5 of Port-B register (pin 5 of Port-B) to provide 5V on pin 13 or clear (LOW) to connect pin 13 to Ground (0V or GND). This is done as,// This turns ON the LEDPORTB |= (1 &lt&lt PB5); // To provide 5V on pin 13// THis turns OFF the LEDPORTB &= ~(1 &lt&lt PB5); // To provide 0V on pin 13The complete program to turn ON the on-board LED is as follows,// Do not worry about the void setup and void loop at this stage// only focus on turning ON the LEDvoid setup(){ // Configure pin 5 on Port-B as output DDRB |= (1 &lt&lt DDB5); // Turn ON the LED PORTB |= (1 &lt&lt PB5);}void loop(){}You can copy the above code on to a new Arduino sketch and upload. The on-board LED should now turn ON. To turn OFF the LED, copy the below code and upload.// Do not worry about the void setup and void loop at this stage// only focus on turning OFF the LEDvoid setup(){ // Configure pin 5 on Port-B as output DDRB |= (1 &lt&lt DDB5); // Turn OFF the LED PORTB &= ~(1 &lt&lt PB5);}void loop(){}Congratulations, you now know how to use a digital pin on an Arduino in output mode. If you feel like writing two different programs and reuploading each time to turn ON or OFF the LED isn't very useful, don't worry, as we slowly build our knowledge of embedded programming, you will be able write complex programs that can do a lot more than just controlling an LED. With this in mind, let us move on to using pin 12 in input mode.Input ModeWe can configure pin 12 by clearing bit-4 of DDRB register. When a particular pin is in input mode, the corresponding bit in PORTB register can be used to enable an on-chip internal pull-up for that pin. Setting the bit enables the pull-up, clearing the bit disables it. For now, we want to use the internal pull-up for pin 12, so we will set bit-4 of PORTB. Below piece of code shows how to configure pin 12 on the Arduino UNO R3 as a digital input pin with internal pull-up enabled. DDRB &= ~(1 &lt&lt DDB4); // Set pin 12 in input modePORTB |= (1 &lt&lt PB4); // Enable internal pull-up for pin 12Now the input status on pin 12 can be read through bit-4 of the PINB register as follows.bool pin12_input_status = false;pin12_input_status = (PINB & (1 &lt&lt PINB4)); We can combine everything in to a single sketch and control the LED on pin 13 using input on pin 12 as follows,void setup(){ // Configure pin 12 as input. DDRB &= ~(1 &lt&lt DDB4); // Set pin 12 in input mode PORTB |= (1 &lt&lt PB4); // Enable internal pull-up for pin 12 // Configure pin 13 as output. DDRB |= (1 &lt&lt DDB5); // Set pin 14 in output mode PORTB &= ~(1 &lt&lt PB5); // Turn OFF the LED}void loop(){ // Declaring bool here is wasteful. // But understandability is important for now. bool pin12_input_status = false; pin12_input_status = (PINB & (1 &lt&lt PINB4)); // if the input on pin 12 is HIGH. // HIGH, true, 1, and 5V are equivalent. if(pin12_input_status) { PORTB |= (1 &lt&lt PB5); // Turn ON the LED } else { PORTB &= ~(1 &lt&lt PB5); // Turn OFF the LED }}After uploading the code to Arduino UNO R3, by default, the LED should turn ON. Now, if you take wire and short circuit pin 12 to the GND pin on the board, you will see the on-board LED turn OFF. Disconnecting pin 12 from GND should bring back the LED to ON state.This code can be further simplified to,void setup(){ // Configure pin 12 as input and pin 13 as output. DDRB = (DDRB & ~(1 &lt&lt DDB4)) | (1 &lt&lt DDB5); PORTB = (PORTB | (1 &lt&lt PB4)) & (~(1 &lt&lt PB5));}void loop(){ // if the input on pin 12 is HIGH. if((PINB & (1 &lt&lt PINB4))) { PORTB |= (1 &lt&lt PB5); // Turn on the LED } else { PORTB &= ~(1 &lt&lt PB5); // Turn off the LED }}
